title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines a "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes. It also defines terms like "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard". The term "rental company" refers to a person engaged in renting or leasing 5 or more motor vehicles for rental or lease purposes. The definitions of "standard" and "person" are also provided in the context of the Safe Rental Car Act of 2011. Prohibition on rental, lease, and sale of defective cars and trucks. Prohibition on rental companies from renting, leasing, or selling defective vehicles after receiving notification from the Secretary of Transportation or manufacturer about safety defects. Rental companies are prohibited from renting, leasing, or selling vehicles that have safety defects unless the issue has been resolved. An exception is made if the Secretary orders a notification and enforcement is set aside in a civil action. The date of receipt of a notification is crucial for rental companies. Rental companies must act promptly upon receiving a notification of a safety defect in a rented or leased vehicle, contacting the renter and any authorized driver immediately. Rental companies must promptly inform renters and authorized drivers of safety defects and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the regulations regarding safety defects in rental vehicles, providing a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. Violation of this Act will be treated as a violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and penalties as the FTC Act. The Act grants privileges and immunities as per the Federal Trade Commission Act. It does not limit the Commission's authority under other laws. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified in certain cases. The attorney general of a State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action under the Act, providing a copy of the complaint. The State must notify the Federal Trade Commission immediately upon starting a civil action. The FTC can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. The section clarifies that state attorney generals can still exercise their powers under state laws and can proceed with legal actions in state or federal court for alleged violations. No separate lawsuit can be initiated under this provision. No separate lawsuit can be brought under this section if the same alleged violation is already the subject of a pending action by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on rental companies selling motor vehicles without standard safety features typically included for consumers. The report will detail the buying practices of rental companies in this regard. The Administrator must report to Congress on rental companies selling motor vehicles without standard safety features and provide recommendations for regulatory actions to protect consumers. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies that may have safety defects or not comply with safety standards within 180 days of the Act's enactment. During the period when rental companies are aware of potential vehicle defects or non-compliance, they must report to the Secretary of Transportation. The report required by title 49, United States Code, must include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles with defects related to motor vehicle safety or non-compliance with safety standards. The Administrator must submit a report on the sales of covered vehicles with defects related to motor vehicle safety or non-compliance with safety standards. The report should include a discussion on the effects of such sales on consumers and any recommendations for legislative and administrative action to address or mitigate these effects. Additionally, a follow-up report on the sales of covered vehicles must be submitted to Congress within 1 year after the initial report. The report on sales of covered vehicles with defects related to safety standards must be submitted by the Administrator, including analysis, recommendations, and identification of differences. The report required by the Administrator must include an analysis of differences between findings, effects of the Act on sales of covered vehicles.
